Equipment List to produce 8 RRA/day in a single shift
Equipment List to produce 8 RRA/day
in a single shift

• Doublet Fixtures (2) • Doublet storing rack (1) • RPC Assembly Fixture (3) • RRA storing rack (1) • Gas Leak Tester (3) • Misc. Tools; Screw guns, small clamp fixtures, standard hand tools, etc. • Material Handling Equipment

Conclusions
Conclusions

• RRA base design is reasonably complete
• RRA base design is reasonably complete

– Minor details remain, no “showstoppers” – Quantity lends itself well to mass production techniques for parts; stamping,
– Minor details remain, no “showstoppers”
– Quantity lends itself well to mass production techniques for parts; stamping,

injection molding, extrusion, etc.
injection molding, extrusion, etc.

• Relatively simple assembly techniques
• Relatively simple assembly techniques

– Material handling issues dominate and will require efficient tooling – Straight forward fixturing/tooling will provide needed efficiencies due to the
– Material handling issues dominate and will require efficient tooling
– Straight forward fixturing/tooling will provide needed efficiencies due to the

volume of repeated tasks
volume of repeated tasks

this
this

• Further concentrated effort on assembly techniques and tolling will inevitably increase
• Further concentrated effort on assembly techniques and tolling will inevitably increase

Particle Board Stress Tests
Particle Board Stress Tests

Manufacturers produce values that are valid for very specific loadings. Varying density across thickness prohibits trivially generalizing test results. Must provide our own tests. Currently using internal bond (80psi) as stress limit in design. This value that will cause mid plane failure (where it is least dense) when applying tension perpendicular to the faces. We need to provide our own data for physical constants Preliminary test results at ANL indicate this value is conservative by at least a factor of 4 for the types of loading we care about (high tensile stresses can be avoided)
Manufacturers produce values that are valid for very specific
loadings. Varying density across thickness prohibits trivially l o a d i n g s .

value that will cause mid plane failure (where it is least dense) when
applying tension perpendicular to the faces.
We need to provide our own data for physical constants
Preliminary test results at ANL indicate this value is conservative by
at least a factor of 4 for the types of loading we care about (high
tensile stresses can be avoided)
